attributes.title: Qualcomm: Increasingly Bearish Investment Thesis
summary: QCOM's rally had been overly fast and furious, with the management offering sobering FY2024 commentary, triggering the stock's subsequent plunge by ~10%.
The loss of AAPL/ Huawei revenues, elongated smartphone replacement cycle, and intensified automotive SaaS market competition, its prospects remain uncertain.
While QCOM may have formed great partnerships on generative AI works, it remains to be seen how much contribution they may make to its top and bottom lines.
While we applaud the management's painful transparency, we believe it may be more prudent to monitor the situation a little longer before jumping in.
The correction may not be over.
attributes.disclosure:

attributes.content:
The QCOM Investment Thesis Is Unlikely To Outperform At These Levels

We previously covered Qualcomm (NASDAQ:QCOM) in May 2023, discussing the stock's mixed prospects, attributed to the ongoing semi and personal device correction. Combined with the uncertain macroeconomic outlook and underwhelming forward guidance, we had concluded with a Hold rating then, due to the potential volatility in the near term.

For now, the headwinds have yet to lift for QCOM, since it reports impacted QCT handset revenues of $5.25B (-13.9% QoQ/ -25.4% YoY) in FQ3'23, comprising 62.1% of its overall top-line (-3.7 points QoQ/ -2.3 YoY).

Since the semi company supplies modems to Apple (AAPL), Samsung (OTCPK:SSNLF), and Huawei, amongst others, it is important to note that the smartphone correction is not over yet, as similarly reflected in their recent earnings call.

For example, AAPL reported lower iPhone sales of $39.66B (-22.7% QoQ/ -2.4% YoY), with SSNLF recording similar weak demand with Mobile eXperience sales of 24.61T KRW (-19.9% QoQ/ -12.1% YoY) in the latest quarter.

With these headwinds attributed to the elevated interest rate environment and tightened discretionary spending, it is unsurprising that market sentiments surrounding QCOM's prospects have been uncertain over the past few quarters.

This is because AAPL's business is reportedly worth nearly $9B in annualized revenues, comprising ~20% of its top-line, worsened by the loss of forward revenue stream from Huawei.

Therefore, with the CEO of QCOM reiterating no further updates to AAPL's modem plans in 2024, it is likely that the semi company's previous statement (highlighted in bold for emphasis) in the Mobile World Congress may hold true:

We're making no plans for 2024, my planning assumption is we're not providing [Apple] a modem in '24, but it's their decision to make. [CNBC]

As a result of the steep top/ bottom line cliff ahead, we are uncertain about QCOM's mixed prospects in the near term, since the global smartphone market's sell-through continues to decline QoQ/ YoY for the eighth consecutive quarter.

While much of the pessimism may have been priced in, we do not think that the semi company's IoT and Automotive segments' performance may be able to balance the handset headwinds in the intermediate term. This is why.

QCOM's IoT revenues have been underwhelming at $1.48B (+6.4% QoQ/ -23.7% YoY) for now, likely attributed to the ongoing cloud capex optimization from the peak recessionary fears and prolonged inventory draw down from the hyper pandemic heights.

The same has been observed in the semi company's elevated inventory levels of $6.62B (-3.3% QoQ/ +22.3% YoY) in FQ3'23, compared to FY2021 levels of $3.22B (+24.3% YoY) and FY2019 levels of $1.4B (-17.1% YoY).

QCOM's performance in the automotive segment remains uncertain as well, despite the growing revenues of $434M (-2.9% QoQ/ +12.7% YoY) in the latest quarter and last reported ADAS design win pipeline of over $30B in FQ4'22.

The semi company will have to contend with Nvidia (NVDA) DRIVE Orin's expanding automotive pipeline of $14B (+27.2% YoY) and accelerating quarterly revenues of $296M (+1% QoQ/ +114% YoY) in Q1'23. Given NVDA's supposed lead in generative AI and other SaaS segments, there is a good chance that the automotive SaaS market may remain intensely competitive.

Therefore, while QCOM may have formed great partnerships with Meta (META) and Microsoft (MSFT) on generative AI works, it remains to be seen how much contribution they may make to the former's top and bottom lines in the near-term, due to the underwhelming commentary (highlighted in bold for emphasis) from the management in the recent earnings call:

As we approach fiscal '24, our revenue growth will largely depend on macroeconomic environment, global handset units, and China recovery... In addition, we expect a sequential decline in IoT and automotive revenues, consistent with the seasonal trend we've seen in the last couple of years... Until we see sustained signs of improving fundamentals, our operating framework does not assume an immediate recovery.

While we applaud the management's painful transparency, we believe it may be more prudent to monitor the situation a little longer before jumping in.

So, Is QCOM Stock A Buy, Sell, or Hold?

QCOM 5Y EV/Revenue and P/E Valuations

For now, QCOM is still trading rather optimistically at NTM EV/ Revenues of 3.88x and NTM P/E of 13.83x, compared to its 1Y mean of 3.59x/ 11.98x, while nearing its 3Y pre-pandemic mean of 3.52x/ 16.74x.

This is because the semi company's top and bottom line recovery have yet to fully materialize, with its valuations and stock price recovery very much pulled forward.

Based on QCOM's forward guidance of FY2023 EPS of $8.29 (-33.8% YoY) at the midpoint and its NTM valuations, our near-term price target of $118.38 has been fully baked in as well, suggesting minimal upside potential from current levels.

While the semi company's prospects may recover over the next few years, we believe any pessimistic news may also trigger further volatility in its stock prices.

QCOM 3Y Stock Price

We have already seen the QCOM stock experience a dramatic pullback by over -10% post FQ3'23 earnings call, thanks to the sobering forward commentary.

While the stock appears to be well supported at current levels, we maintain our belief that the stock's recovery has been too fast and furious since the May 2023 bottom, likely lifted by the supposed bull run market since the start of the year.

With its prospects unlikely to lift in the near term, we do not recommend anyone to add QCOM here. Bottom fishing investors may consider waiting for a retracement to low $100s for an improved margin of safety.

Editor's Note: This article discusses one or more securities that do not trade on a major U.S. exchange. Please be aware of the risks associated with these stocks.

attributes.bio:
I am a full-time analyst interested in a wide range of stocks. With my unique insights and knowledge, I hope to provide other investors with a contrasting view of my portfolio, given my particular background.

If you have any questions, feel free to reach out to me via a direct message on Seeking Alpha or leave a comment on one of my articles.
